entry.title: Re: Selecting participants and structuring the workshop effectively.
entry.content:
Thank you, Klaus, for your question.

You're absolutely right: getting the right mix of expertise in the room isn’t always easy, but it really does make a difference. Having both subject-matter experts and technical experts involved leads to more grounded and actionable ideas, and it might be better to plan the workshop with enough time in advance to find the right experts, rather than having only one perspective covered.

One way to maintain the balance between ideation and feasibility discussions is by creating space for different perspectives at different stages of the workshop. During the ideation exercise, participants work individually and silently, which encourages a wide range of creative input without immediate feasibility concerns. Later, in the prioritization phase, the group reflects together on which ideas are both valuable and viable — and this is where technical experts can play a key role by identifying potential quick wins or flagging areas that might be more complex.

It’s also helpful to remember that this workshop happens early in the process. The goal isn’t to validate every technical detail, but rather to spot high-potential opportunities that are worth exploring further. Comprehensive feasibility checks will come later, during the design and implementation phases, when ideas are refined and solutions start to take shape. Often, what may initially seem difficult can be approached in creative or phased ways.

entry.title: Date Time as a Custom Filter Field
entry.content:
Hi 
I am designing an CAP Based Fiori application , In my List Report Page I have some Filters startDateTIme and endDateTime , which accept the dateTime datatype with multiple condition operator , where the values of theses filters are in current local timezone  , but before sending the data to backend they convert into UTC . My query is that is there any way we can make the value of filter to UTC timezone by default instead of converting it from the client side  , or Is there any way to Intecept the GET call so that I can manually convert it to local to UTC of the same values .
Any Help is most welcome 
Thank You .

entry.title: partially committed webservice-transactions in SQL Anywhere
entry.content:
I am hosting webservice inside sql anywhere database, this works fine but I have from time to time problems with uncompleted transactions.
My code looks similar to this snippet.

create or replace table mytable (TS timestamp, msg varchar(100));
create or replace service myservice type 'xml' authorization off user dba as call myproc();
create or replace procedure myproc()
begin
insert into mytable values (now(), 'Start');
--long processing logic replaced with waitfor
waitfor delay '00:00:20';
insert into mytable values (now(), 'End');
select 'finished' from dummy;
end;

For some reason (when the processing too long time takes) I see partial transactions in MYTABLE ('Start' without 'End')

The Webservice is consumed from remote clients but with usual HTTP Calls. I cant exactly read what is the client getting in such uncompleted and partial requests, but probably timeout or 'statement interrupted by user'.

I dont have control on the client and can imagine that some timeout is set by it but how can the transactions of myproc be partially committed (I am sure that I dont have any explicit commit in myproc or somewhere else along the execution of myservice).

The same error could not be reproduced with curl (I call the webservice using curl and stop it after few seconds, then nothing is writting in mytable).

 

My Questions:

  1. Under what circumstances could a SQL Anywhere web service commit a partial transaction, even if there’s no explicit COMMIT?

  2. Could the SQL Anywhere engine implicitly commit parts of a transaction under some conditions (e.g., before an exception or client disconnection)?

  3. Is there a better way to structure or wrap the procedure to ensure atomicity, even in the case of client timeouts or interruptions?

  4. Is it possible to detect or handle client disconnections within the procedure?

Any insights or experiences with similar issues would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: Vendor Evaluation based on LIS - Conversion to S4 HANA
entry.content:
Although Simplification Note 2267414 permits retention of the classic vendor-evaluation solution during your S/4HANA conversion, the SAP S/4HANA Compatibility Scope Matrix (Note 2269324) grants only a limited usage right for all “compatibility-pack” solutions—and that right expires December 31, 2025. Your planned June 2026 go-live falls after this expiration, so the consequences of retaining the old vendor-evaluation logic are:

After 31 Dec 2025, you are no longer licensed to run the compatibility-pack component for vendor evaluation. Continuing to use it would violate your S/4HANA license agreement.

SAP will cease delivering bug-fixes, legal-change updates, or enhancements for the classic solution from January 2026 onward. Any regulatory changes to vendor evaluation (e.g., new scorecards, country-specific metrics) will not be back-ported.

Future S/4HANA releases (post-2025) may technically disable or remove compatibility-pack code entirely. Your conversion readiness checks and EarlyWatch Alert reports will flag the expired component as a high-priority finding—potentially blocking further support package or version upgrades.

What you will see on your converted system is the existing IMG settings, reports, and SAP GUI transactions for classic vendor evaluation will remain visible immediately after go-live. However, any attempts to run batch evaluations or maintain settings will either:

  • Fail with compatibility-pack errors
  • Generate silent data inconsistencies that you cannot correct

Recommended approach is switch to Fiori-based Manage Supplier Evaluation and underlying CDS views. Migrate existing scorecards and custom KPIs using the delivered Data Migration Cockpit objects. Plan a cutover project to retire the classic logic by Q3 2025. Validate all interfaces and custom reports are re-pointed to the new framework. Monitor SAP Notes and Roadmap Explorer for deprecation schedules. Engage SAP Support via an OSS message to confirm any last-minute extension or workaround.

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM - Event configuration for Job & Automation Monitoring to exclude some jobs from alerts
entry.content:
Hello,

We have configured IPS job monitoring from SAP Cloud ALM via Job & Automation Monitoring operation for the provisioning jobs.

However, there are scenarios where the job gets cancelled due to known reasons example email already exists or other SCIM errors which are usually ignored. But for SAP Cloud ALM Job & Automation Monitoring Event configuration, there is no exception for this kind of issues rather the incident creation is based on the status code Red/Yellow etc., 

We appreciate if you can provide a solution for this kind of scenarios, that would be really helpful.

Regards,


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud ALM - Event configuration for Job & Automat...
entry.content:
If specific jobs or scenarios arise where Alerts should not be created, you need to enter more specific parameters and values for the Event filters. This is the only mechanism available to prevent specific jobs or scenarios from contributing to an Alert in Job & Automation Monitoring. For example, you mentioned that some SCIM errors are usually ignored. You should use a combination of parameters, the "is not" operator, and values related to the SCIM job errors you want to omit to ensure they are not considered as part of the event calculations for generating alerts. By adding filters, you can be more specific about exactly what contributes to your alerts.

More information on entering Event Filters for Job & Automation Monitoring Events is documented in the Configuration section of the Job & Automation Monitoring setup guide.

entry.title: Re: Differentiate tax code for normal PO and subcontracti...
entry.content:
SAP’s standard tax‐determination in OBYZ only lets you key off fields that are delivered in the “field catalog” of the tax condition tables (country, material-tax class, vendor-tax class, etc.).

While I am wondering as to why adding the PO type to standard configuration is not considered, if your business forbids adding PO type or item category to those tables, there’s no purely IMG‐based way to have the system pick a different tax code for “standard PO” vs. “subcontracting PO” on the same article/vendor combination.

Below are your two realistic “standard” paths—one stays strictly in IMG, the other leverages a SAP‐delivered enhancement point.


You can exploit the “vendor subrange” field (LFM1-LFSNR) in your tax condition tables instead of PO type. In SPRO → Tax on Sales/Purchases → Check Calculation Procedure → Define Condition Tables, pick the standard table M/05 (which already contains vendor-subrange). In your access sequence (SPRO → Define Access Sequences), move that table to the top.

Maintain two vendor-subranges for the same supplier:

  • Subrange 01 = standard PO → tax code A
  • Subrange 02 = subcontracting PO → tax code B

When users create a subcontracting PO, they pick Subrange 02 in the vendor master (or you default it via partner determination).

Pros:
Pure IMG (no ABAP).
Fully supported.

Cons:
Vendor master change required for each PO scenario (you’re just shifting complexity).
Customer still touches “vendor‐subrange” in the vendor master.

SAP ships an enhancement spot inside the tax engine so you can override the tax code logic based on any PO header field—including PO type—even though it isn’t in OBYZ. In transaction SE18/SE19 look for BAdI FIPP_TAX_DETERM (or class‐based enhancement in function group FIPR around CALCULATE_TAX_ITEMS).

Pros:
Transparent to end users (no new IMG objects).
Locks tax‐determination firmly in one spot.

Cons:
Requires a small ABAP enhancement—even though it’s on a SAP‐supported enhancement spot.

entry.title: Re: Enforce required Data Collections upon Operation Complete within SAP Digital Manufacturing
entry.content:
Hi @antoniomasseretti, that should be possible via API, or using Special Operations or Disposition Routings to bring the SFC back to Active, so you can capture the Data Collection using Standard PODs. You can also evaluate using Nonconformance POD, which shows 'Done' SFCs, but I suspect Data Collection plugins will not work there.

Another option is to create a Custom POD Plugin or Custom Development in BTP as a UI to trigger and call the API, if handling API calls directly is not an option.

Finally, you can wait for POD 2.0 release, currently in closed BETA, open BETA in 2511 and GA planned for 2602, which would make such customizations much easier and simple using ootb capabilities.

Hope it helps,
Manoel

entry.title: Re: Issue with Deep Entity Set After OData Service Regene...
entry.content:
Hi @panchalal1023-5 

Thanks for reaching out.

The issue with deep entity sets after regenerating OData services is often related to missing or misaligned associations/navigation properties in the metadata.

Here is what I suggest resolving the issue:

Ensure that the deep entity relationships are still correctly defined in the data model especially after regeneration.

If you’re using SEGW, verify or reimplement the DEFINE_DEEP_ENTITY and related methods in your DPC_EXT class to ensure they're handling the structure correctly post-regeneration.

You can run /IWBEP/CACHE_CLEANUP and clear the metadata cache in your front-end system.

Recheck the metadata document for any inconsistencies or missing complex types.

If the service was extended or consumed in Fiori/UI5, ensure that the UI is still aligned with the regenerated structure.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Push notifications using SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
Hi Vladyslav,

Great question — you're definitely not alone in running into this challenge when working with SAP Build Apps and push notifications.

You're on the right track trying to use Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM), but there are a few key things to understand when working with SAP Build Apps (no-code) and trying to enable push notifications on mobile devices. Here's a structured breakdown of what’s happening and how you can proceed:


Summary of What’s Happening
You're using the "Request Notification Permissions" action from the Marketplace.

You're testing on an iPhone with the SAP Build Apps Preview App.

You’re receiving an undefined error and can’t retrieve the device token.

 

Important Limitation
Push notifications don’t work in the Preview App.

This is a known limitation — the Preview App doesn't support push notification services like FCM or APNs (Apple Push Notification Service). The actions might exist in the logic flow, but the Preview App lacks the native configuration (like embedded Firebase SDK) to make it functional.

To test and use push notifications, you must:

Build and install a standalone version of your app (APK for Android, IPA for iOS).

For iOS, you need to configure APNs certificates and publish via TestFlight or use a physical device with proper provisioning.


Suggested Implementation Approach
Step 1: Setup Firebase Project
Create a Firebase project at  console.firebase.google.com

Enable Cloud Messaging.

Download the google-services.json (for Android) and GoogleService-Info.plist (for iOS) files.

Step 2: Add Firebase Plugin (SAP Build Apps)
In SAP Build Apps, go to Marketplace → Plugins.

Install the Firebase Push Notifications plugin.

Configure it using your Firebase credentials.

You may need to use the Custom Plugins feature if a complete Firebase plugin isn't available in Marketplace.

Step 3: Build Your App
Go to Launch → Distribute.

Generate the build for Android or iOS with your Firebase configuration included.

Install it on a real device.

Step 4: Request Permissions & Get Token
Use the logic flow:

Request Notification Permissions

Get FCM Token (or equivalent)

Save the token (e.g., to SAP BTP or Firebase DB)

Step 5: Send Push Notifications
Use FCM HTTP v1 API to send notifications:

Via your backend (SAP BTP, Firebase Functions, or any cloud function)

Manually via Firebase Console for testing

About SAP Mobile Services
You're right that SAP Mobile Services is better documented for MDK or Fiori apps. At the moment, direct integration between SAP Build Apps and Mobile Services is not natively supported for no-code apps without a lot of customization. It’s mostly useful for apps built using the SAP Mobile SDK.

So for now, FCM is a more practical route.

Resources
 Firebase Cloud Messaging Docs

 SAP Build Apps Docs

Community post with a workaround:  Example Setup using Firebase + SAP Build Apps (Search for Firebase in SAP Build Apps)

Final Thoughts

You're close! The main issue is using the Preview App, which won’t support push notifications. Once you build a native version of your app and configure Firebase properly, you should be able to request permissions, retrieve the device token, and send push notifications using FCM.

Let me know if you'd like a minimal example project or walkthrough for building the app with push enabled — happy to help!

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Adjusting S4 Delivery quantity using process code fro...
entry.content:
Hi @Arjun_Mukherjee 

Thank you for your detailed explanation.

@KB47, I hope the following helps  you too.

You are right, in embedded EWM on S/4HANA, when using exception code BIDF during picking, the EWM delivery quantity gets zeroed, and PGI completes successfully. However, the S/4 outbound delivery doesn’t update automatically unless you manually trigger the notification via the “Outbound Delivery” button.

This behaviour is expected because in embedded setups, O002 behaves like O001, meaning the system does not automatically push changes to S/4 upon WT confirmation. Unlike decentralized EWM, there's no automatic delivery update in S/4 for zero quantity unless explicitly triggered.

To automate this, one option is to implement a custom enhancement or BADI for example BADI_EWM_DELIV_UPDATE to push the quantity update from EWM to S/4 immediately after the exception is processed.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Groovy scrit error when canonicalize XML subtree
entry.content:
Hi Ivan,

>> Sincerely grateful for any suggestion which can avoid the namespace and format changed during the canonicalize() method run.

An XML document can be changed by diffrent parsers and other software. That's why we have to make sure that both sides work with a document in the same format. When you create a digital signature you have to specify the canonicalization method. It will be added to your XML document (CanonicalizationMethod tag). On the receiver side this method will be used to transform a document to the same format as it was on the sender side.  That's why we need the canonicalization process.

BR,

Andrzej

entry.title: Re: UAE VAT
entry.content:
S/4HANA lets you maintain all of a supplier’s VAT registrations on one Business Partner (BP) – you don’t need three different vendor masters for Mainland, Free-Zone and Overseas. What you do need is:

Maintain each VAT registration with its Type/Category on the BP. Configure the Place-of-Supply and Tax Determination rules to pick up that Type. In your PO or Invoice, pick the “right” registration—and SAP will flow in the correct tax code.

Below is the standard, no-customization recipe.

In Fiori App, select Manage Business Partner, Open your Supplier BP → Identification → Tax Numbers – Add one entry for each VAT registration – Choose Type = e.g. Mainland, Free-Zone, Overseas (you’ll see these labels once you’ve done step 2) – Fill in the 15-digit registration number. This gives you a list of three registrations, each with its own “VAT Reg. No.” + Type.

Define Tax Number Types (SSCUI 103042) – You’ll see codes like 01 Mainland, 02 FreeZone, 03 Overseas. Maintain Tax Number Type Descriptions (SSCUI 103043) – Ensure your labels match your business jargon. These steps populate the drop-down on the BP Tax Numbers screen so your team can pick the right Category.

SAP uses “Place of Supply” as the pivot for GCC tax logic. You tell the system—“when I buy from a BP under this VAT Type, treat it as Domestic vs. Free Zone vs. Export”: This you can do in Fiori App Manage Your Solution → search “Place of Supply” – Create/Check entries such as:

  • Tax Number Type = ‘01 Mainland’ → Place of Supply = Domestic
  • Tax Number Type = ‘02 FreeZone’ → Place of Supply = FreeZone
  • Tax Number Type = ‘03 Overseas’ → Place of Supply = Export.

These rules feed into the built-in UAE tax procedure.

Once the place of supply is known, SAP’s standard UAE tax procedure (TAXAEN) will select:

• 5% Input VAT (V2) for Domestic
• 0% for Free-Zone (V1 or V0 – per your configuration)
• 0% Export (V0) for Overseas

You do not need extra fields in OBYZ or custom BAdIs. In your Create Purchase Order (or Invoice) screen. Pick the Supplier BP. In the Tax/ Invoice section, choose the VAT Reg. No. (the Type you want). SAP automatically picks the correct VAT code for that line

entry.title: Re: Using Log Buyoff for Process Orders in SAP DM.
entry.content:
Hi, see Custom POD , where it reads:

The Custom POD type can be used for any industry that needs a custom POD selection or no POD selection. It supports creation of a custom POD which offers specific features not provided by a core POD type. It is incumbent on the creator of the custom POD to ensure that the POD has the data and configuration needed to work as desired.

Which means that, for a Custom POD, you either create a custom POD selection plugin or use no POD selection at all. If I´m not mistaken, you can find examples in GitHub.

Generally speaking, ootb Buy Off capability is not supported for Process Industries, so I suggest you explore implementing your own buy off logic with custom developments and extensions.

Hope it helps! Br, Manoel

entry.title: Re: When we do print preview getting file corrupted on bi...
entry.content:
When you trigger Print Preview for a billing document (VF02 → Extras → Issue Output → Print Preview) and the PDF comes back corrupted, it usually means the OTF-to-PDF conversion or Adobe form processing has broken somewhere. 

In order to isolate the issue, in VF03, use Extras → Issue Output To → Print Preview. Note whether the system creates a new spool request (transaction SP01). Download the spool body as PDF and open it with Acrobat Reader. Try another form (e.g. a standard purchase order via ME23N) to see if PDF conversion works globally. This tells you if the problem is specific to billing forms or a general Adobe/OTF conversion issue.

Check Post-Processing Profile & Printer Setup.
This you can do via Transaction SPAD → Devices/Servers → Output Devices. Make sure your device (e.g., LOCL) is defined with access method “HOSTPRINT” or “DIRECT" and uses the PDF1 device type.

SPRO → SAP NetWeaver → Application Server → Printing → Postprocessing for Form Output. Assign your output device to the post-processing function class FP (Forms Processing). Confirm that your device uses the FP-PDF driver for PDF conversion. If your device is pointing to an XPR or TXT driver, all you’ll get is gibberish when you open it as PDF.

You can check some SAP notes which are

2488510 – “FP-PDF: PDF file displays as gibberish/text”
2200147 – “Error during ADS PDF generation”
2120512 – “Spool: Invalid PDF due to missing OTF post-processing”

entry.title: Re: Sales document type / Order type is not visible in T-...
entry.content:
Hi @RaviKum 

Thank you for reaching out.

To populate the Sales Doc Type field in J7LTSL, please follow the below described steps:

  1. Maintain reference SD documents in J7LCM.
  2. Check REA document type settings via J7L4.
  3. Activate SD interface mapping via J7LINTV_SD and J7LINTV_SD1.
  4. Ensure REA category mapping is in place for the sales document.
  5. If necessary, apply enhancements via user exit EXIT_SAPMJ7L1_001.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Quality Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP´s ready-to-run public Cloud ERP software solution. SAP S/4HANS Cloud Public Edition is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the Cloud ERP ecosystem – customers, partners, and SAP experts.  

This release introduces a groundbreaking feature: SAP Document AI. The generative AI-powered document processing capability revolutionizes the way businesses manage and process quality certificates, handling them in all formats seamlessly within the SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Designed to extract relevant information and automatically identify corresponding quality certificates, this solution empowers businesses to streamline their processes and achieve remarkable operational efficiencies.



Leveraging generative AI with SAP Document AI

With the launch of the SAP Document AI capability in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release, businesses can now enjoy a new advantage in processing quality certificates. The innovation empowers users to enhance productivity in processing quality certificates while reducing production loss attributable to material inspection delays.

By harnessing the power of generative AI, this feature reduces the time required to process incoming certificates, thereby allowing quality technicians to concentrate on their core functions. This effectively reduces manual effort and associated processing costs. Furthermore, the automation provided by SAP Document AI ensures that no certificates are lost or overlooked, augmenting quality control mechanisms and minimizing errors due to improperly assigned objects.

Through efficient extraction and structuring of information from various quality certificates, SAP Document AI streamlines stock release processes with quicker quality certificate confirmation. The AI-driven solution facilitates the automatic extraction of data from paper or PDF quality certificates, transferring the extracted data into a smart processing queue for seamless handling. Whether through automated processing or intelligent error management, the executed transactions are both reliable and agile.

 

Streamlining certificate management processes

Beyond its AI capabilities, the innovation also introduces application-level improvements that enhance inbound logistics workflows.. By instantly generating certificate receipt confirmation using extracted data, the system ensures a swift and reliable integration of quality certificates into the workflow. Application data is utilized to accurately locate the corresponding quality certificate data records within the SAP system, and these records are efficiently mapped to the quality certificates in the queue. This functionality further enhances the accuracy and efficiency of the document management process

Certificates receive a status update to "received," with the quality certificate document being attached to the relevant system data record. The solution also provides enhanced flexibility, enabling customers to transfer defects to a variety of quality notifications seamlessly.

 

 

AI-powered document processing for incoming supplier quality certificates

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release marks a significant milestone in the digital evolution of quality certificate processing. By integrating generative AI technology into business processes, the AI-powered document processing for incoming supplier quality certificates elevates productivity, accuracy, and reliability while reducing the time and effort involved in managing quality certificates. 

 

📽️ Watch the replays of our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Early Release Series!

Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You will find the recording and presentation for Manufacturing as well as 20 other topics of interest. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand–anywhere, anytime.

entry.title: Re: Mass changes to purchasing info records - Excel forma...
entry.content:
There is no SAP Note on it because it’s 100% on the Excel side. Pick one of the tricks above as a pre-upload step (or record it as a macro), and your mass-update will fly through every time.

When you copy a decimal value out of a formula cell and do a straight Paste-As-Values, Excel often leaves the cell looking like text but without ever running its “Number Stored as Text” check on it—so you don’t get the green-triangle, and the Fiori upload rejects it as “incorrect format.” As soon as you edit the cell (double-click or retype) Excel re-evaluates it, flags it as text-which-looks-like-a-number (green triangle), and then the SAP parser will accept it.

Because this is purely Excel business, the only really bullet-proof fix is to force Excel to recalculate those pasted values so they become actual text-numbers that Excel will flag. Here are three zero-code options:

Text-to-Columns trick • Select your entire “Amount” column in Excel , Go to Data → Text to Columns, Click Next → Next → Finish This runs the column through the import engine and Excel re-evaluates every value. You’ll see the green triangles pop back, and the Fiori upload will accept them.

Paste-Multiply method • In an empty cell type the number 1 and copy it, Select your pasted values → Paste Special → Multiply,  Then Paste Special → Values back over them Multiplying by 1 forces a true numeric conversion, then putting them back as values gives you a consistent text-number format.

VALUE() formula • In a helper column use =VALUE( its_formula_cell ) • Copy the results and Paste-Values into your upload sheet VALUE() coerces Excel to churn out a “pure” number as text, complete with the green-triangle flag.

Once you see the green triangles on all your decimal cells, save the workbook and do the offline upload again—the “not in correct format” errors will disappear.

Why it happens is because Excel’s “number stored as text” error check only flags user-typed or VALUE()/-converted text-numbers, not raw formula results. SAP’s Fiori Excel parser looks for that same pattern to know it can safely strip the apostrophe/convert it back to a number.

entry.title: Inability to modify BP Bank Account on KA journal entry type via "edit line items"
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

We are currently facing a functional limitation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition  related to the modification of the bank account on KA journal entry type documents.

🧭 Functional Context

Previously, it was possible to edit the bank account (RIB) on KA journal entries using the “Manage Supplier Line Items” app and the “edit line items” function.
Interestingly, the same modification still works for ZP journal entry type, which has been confirmed through user testing.

📌Customer Case

  • The issue was observed while trying to update the BP Bank Account  for suppliers.
  • The system throws an error when attempting to modify the RIB via “edit line items”.
  • Example error message:
    “Impossible de modifier Cpte bq parten. pour le poste 1700000079/2025/001”
    (Unable to change bank account for item 1700000079/2025/001)

⚠️Business Impact

  • The KA journal entry type is mandatory for vendor down payments.
  • This restriction prevents users from correcting or updating the RIB, which can lead to:
    • Payments being sent to incorrect bank accounts
    • Delays in payment processing
    • Reduced reliability of vendor banking data

📝Additional Notes

  • Previously, we were able to modify the RIB on both KA and ZP entries.
  • These entries allowed RIB modification in the past. However, recent tests in the quality environment using similar journal entry types no longer allow RIB modification for KA entries.

❓Request for Insights

We would appreciate any feedback or clarification from the community or SAP experts on the following points:

  1. Is this a new limitation introduced in version 2502, or a bug?
  2. Is this behavior now considered standard SAP for KA journal entry type?
  3. Are there any planned enhancements to restore RIB modification for KA entries?
  4. What workarounds or configuration options exist to address this issue?

Thank you in advance for your support and insights!
— Anis BEN SALEM, Senior Associate

entry.title: Re: advanced ATP for third party sales orders
entry.content:
ABC’s plant substitution will happily generate a CB1 (or CBAB) subitem in your NORM‐type order, but that subitem uses the standard schedule‐line category for external procurement (CS) and PR type from your ATP setup. If that PR type isn’t allowed or no valid source-of-supply exists in the system for that material–plant–vendor combination, you’ll get “purchase requisition could not be created.”

Make sure you have a valid source for the PR. In your Cloud system, open the Fiori app Manage Sourcing Profile. Under your substitution strategy, check that for Item Category Usage ABC2 (subitem) you have: Procurement type = External Procurement; Default Purchase Requisition Type (e.g. “NB”); Source Determination = Info Record. Now, in Manage Business Partner Addresses (or Manage Supplier Master Data), ensure you have a Purchasing Info Record for Material X + Supplier Y + Plant Z and the Info Record is valid for the date and quantity (you already did this). Go to Manage Master Data for Sourcing and maintain a Source List entry for the same combination (Material X + Plant Z + Supplier Y). – In Cloud, if you skip the source list the PR can’t find the vendor – the system treats the source list as mandatory for external procurement unless you allow “Info Record only.”

In Fiori Configure Your Solution (or SSCUI), search “Schedule Line Category”. Pull up your CS entry (the standard “subcontracting”-type category chosen by ABC). Make sure PR Type is set correctly (e.g. NB), Automatic Source Determination is switched on and Allowed Proc. Types includes External (F)

Any help or insight would be greatly appreciated

 

Regards

entry.title: Re: In Freight Pricing Condition what is the difference b...
entry.content:
Dear,

Account key:the G/L account to which the condition amount is posted (actual freight cost).effect of MIRO invoice and Actual Expense Account.

Accrual (Accrual Key):the G/L account for posting an estimated/temporary cost (like freight) during Goods Receipt (GR).effect on MIGO and Clearing / Accrual Account.

During GR, only the Accrual key is used, and the Account key is ignored.

Thanks.

entry.title: Re: SAP Group Reporting : document number for realignment...
entry.content:
When you assign document type GR to realignment, you’re only telling the system which FI document type to use. The actual number range doesn’t come from OMBA (the MM/material‐document number‐range table) but from the FI/general‐ledger number‐range configuration. Realignment postings in Group Reporting are plain FI journal entries against the consolidation ledger, so their numbering follows the FI number‐range object, not the MM one.

In OMBA, document‐type GR → number ranges applies only to material documents (MIGO, MB01, etc.). Realignment uses FI document numbering (object FI_DOCNR / FBN1/OBA7). Even though you chose “GR” as the doc type, the system looks into the FI number‐range assignments for that doc type, company code, and ledger.

To answer your question "How the System Picks the Number", You trigger a realignment run (via Fiori or the consolidation‐data realignment job). The job reads your realignment‐to‐doc‐type mapping (you mapped your function to “GR”). When it creates the FI entry in ACDOCA, it calls the FI number‐range object. The system checks OBA7 (or FBN1 in old releases) for a number‐range interval assigned to:

  • Your company code
  • Document type “GR”
  • The consolidation ledger (ledger group) in which the posting lands

It picks the next free number from that interval. If no interval is defined, it takes the first internal range it finds.

What you need to do to Control the Number is Go to SPRO → Financial Accounting → General Ledger → Document → Document Number Ranges → Define Document Types and Number Ranges. For your company code and consolidation ledger, assign a number‐range interval to doc type GR. Make sure your consolidation‐ledger group is tied to the same GL number‐range object (check ledger‐group customizing in Group Reporting). Run the realignment again—the next free number from your newly assigned FI interval will be used.

entry.title: SAP ECTR for SAP S/4HANA 1.3 - What’s new in the new major Release
entry.content:
The new major Release of SAP ECTR for SAP S/4HANA 1.3 has been available since July 17, 2025. In this blog post, we present significant enhancements and provide insights into why this release marks an important milestone.

With SAP ECTR, our mission is clear: deliver an innovative, integrated, and future-proof solution built on SAP, empowering companies to support product lifecycle management process while strengthening their competitiveness in the market. This mission is supported by a strategy built on two core principles:

  • ERP-Integrated PLM
    Today, more than ever, businesses require their PLM processes to be seamlessly embedded into their ERP processes.  Only when PLM processes are operating as an integral part of SAP Business Suite can organizations unlock the full potential of end-to-end process integration across the entire supply chain.
  • Hybrid Solution Scenarios
    The complexity of IT landscapes continues to grow, driven by an increasing number of cloud solutions. Hybrid integration is essential to connect existing and new systems in a unified user interface - enabling seamless processes across system boundaries.

This release introduces numerous innovations that also enhance engineering processes and user experience. Below, we highlight the four most important new features, followed by an explanation of why a major release was necessary.

#1 Plant View Assignment for Materials

A key enhancement for ERP-integrated PLM processes is the ability to assign a plant to multiple materials in bulk directly within SAP ECTR.

This functionality significantly streamlines the creation of MBOMs (MRP-enabled BOMs), making it easier and faster to prepare accurate structures and ensure downstream ERP processes receive the correct data.

#2 Extended External Generic Object Framework

External Generic Object (EGO) technology was introduced in version 1.2.1, which enables the integration of external objects via RESTful APIs. With the help of EGO technology, data/objects from external systems are displayed, accessed, and linked as SAP ECTR objects, ensuring consistent user experience. This integration serves as the foundation for hybrid solutions.

These capabilities have been further expanded and optimized in SAP ECTR for SAP S/4HANA 1.3. On the one hand, the EGO technology creates the foundation for customers and partners to integrate additional external systems and their object world. A How-to-Guide is available here: How to integrate external (cloud) solutions via OSGi Generic Objects in Hybrid scenarios | SAP Help Portal

On the other hand, "file-based collaboration" has been implemented as a new functionality in SAP ECTR to enable file-based integration with the SAP IPD Collaboration capability.

“File-based collaboration” in SAP ECTR

Users can now integrate SAP IPD Collaboration directly within SAP ECTR. Documents and their originals can be imported via drag & drop, while collaboration objects are fully visible and linked within the SAP ECTR desktop.

#3 Support of Preconditions (Object Dependencies) for Characteristic Values

A long-standing improvement request from customers is now reality. The new capabilty of supporting preconditons as object dependencies for characteristic values enables configuration logic during classification. For example, if the characteristic MANUFACTURER is set to “VW,” users will only see VW-specific models. This feature greatly improves data accuracy and simplifies variant configuration scenarios.

#4 Ad-Hoc Messaging for Enhanced Collaboration

To improve user communication and speed up decision-making, we introduce a new “Share Objects” feature. Users can now send ad-hoc messages directly from any object within SAP ECTR.

Recipients receive instant notifications and can respond immediately, facilitating efficient collaboration without leaving the SAP ECTR environment.

Why a new major Release?

Every major Release of SAP ECTR for SAP S/4HANA is aligned with a specific SAP S/4HANA Version as foundation. SAP ECTR for SAP S/4HANA 1.3 is based on SAP S/4HANA 2023 to leverage new capabilities and ensure long-term support.

In the case of SAP ECTR for SAP S/4HANA 1.2 , this foundation was SAP S/4HANA 2021.

Now, the correlation in general is that the SAP ECTR for SAP S/4HANA major Release has the same End of Mainstream Maintenance (EoM) date as the foundation (SAP S/4HANA Version) on which it is based. For SAP ECTR for SAP S/4HANA 1.2, this means that the EoM date is at least as the EoM date for SAP S/4HANA 2021. This is at least December 31, 2026.

The planning for SAP ECTR Releases can be found here: Release Strategy and Planning of Support Packages for SAP ECTR | SAP Help Portal

Summary

With SAP ECTR for SAP S/4HANA 1.3, we continue our journey to deliver flexible, ERP-integrated, and hybrid-ready PLM solutions that support end-to-end digitalization strategies.

The new release focuses on:

  • Strengthening engineering processes through advanced functionalities
  • Expanding integration with ERP and external systems to provide a unified PLM experience

Additional Information

For a complete list of features and improvements, visit What's New in SAP ECTR 1.3 for SAP S/4HANA | SAP Help Portal.
And there are a bunch of great videos showing the new features of SAP ECTR for SAP S/4HANA 1.3.
Check out the SAP ECTR Road Map on the SAP Road Map Explorer for further planned functions and capabilities.

Please share your feedback and thoughts in a comment.
You can also follow me on the SAP Community to stay up to date!
If you are interested in more PLM relevant topics, I encourage you to read other blog posts here.

About the author

Dominik Maier is Senior Vice President Products & Development and Member of the Management Board at DSC Software AG, an SAP Platinum Partner for PLM. Follow him on LinkedIn to get the latest news about PLM in SAP and DSC Software AG.

entry.title: Re: Inability to modify BP Bank Account on KA journal ent...
entry.content:
Users can still change the bank account (RIB) on ZP-type supplier line items in the “Manage Supplier Line Items” app, but attempting the same for KA-type (vendor down-payment) items now triggers the error you’ve observed. This isn’t a transient bug introduced only in 2502—it reflects the delivered scope of editable fields for down-payment line categories in the public-cloud solution.

Standard behavior Vs Bug
The inability to change the bank account on KA items is by design in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502. It is not flagged as a correction in the release notes nor covered by an SAP Note as an “error” in 2502. Instead, only ZP (invoice/credit memo) categories carry the business-partner-bank-account field into the embedded “edit line items” framework. Because KA entries represent down-payment requests, their line-item UI groups omit the RIB field in the editable field list.

How SAP Controls Editable Fields in “Manage Supplier Line Items”
The app’s field-selection logic is delivered via SAP-managed field-group annotations (not via SPRO). In the backend, each supplier-line-item category (invoice, credit memo, down-payment, etc.) maps to a specific editable-fields definition. For KA items, the delivered field group omits the bank-account property—you’ll see it greyed-out or locked even though the doc type GR/KA exists. ZP items leverage a different annotation set that includes the bank-account field, so you can switch BPs’ IBAN or RIB there without error.

As of the 2502 Feature Scope Description and 2502.1 What’s New guides, there’s no mention of RIB editing for down-payment line items3. SAP has not committed to an immediate enhancement in the Q1/Q2 2025 roadmap for this specific field-group extension.

Below are some workarounds

  • Reverse & repost - Reverse the KA down-payment document and repost with the correct bank-account in one step.
  • Post a manual journal - Use the “Manage Journal Entries” app (F0717A) to post an FI journal that mimics the down payment but includes the desired RIB. This entry posts directly to the clearing account and can then be used to clear vendor open items.
  • Custom API/Integration - Invoke BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST or the OData service for supplier-line-item change to push an update outside the standard UI. You’ll need to handle change-log and audit controls.
  • Central vendor-master update - If the down payment should always use a different account, update the vendor’s default bank info. While this won’t change existing KA entries, it prevents future errors.

entry.title: Custom Fiori app displays placeholder instead of actual value from Odata
entry.content:
The app is connected to an odata service that gets data from vbak. I am trying to display the Sales Document Number 

CurrentExpected
Sales document no(header)Sales document no (header)
SalesDocument_01000000123
SalesDocument_01000000124
SalesDocument_01000000125

In my cds: it is declared that 

key vbak.vbeln  as SalesDocument

XML
<smartTable:SmartTable>
 <Table items="{Z_VBAKTEST}">
  <columns>
   <Column>
    <Text text="Sales Document No">
   <Column>
  </columns>
  <items>
   <ColumnListItem>
    <Text text="{SalesDocument}"/>
   <ColumnListItem>
  </items>
 </Table>
</smartTable:SmartTable>

entry.title: SAP Signavio Process Governance
entry.content:
Hallo zusammen,

Wir haben folgende Herausforderung.

Wir sind gerade dabei, Process Governance einzurichten und haben einen ersten Versuch zur Erstellung eines automatischen Workflows wieder gelöscht.

Leider erhalten wir seitdem täglich die folgende Meldung:

"Signavio Approval Workflow nicht gefunden"

"Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren"

bei der Überprüfung der geplanten Genehmigungen für heute ist der folgende Fehler aufgetretenDer in der Konfiguration Genehmigungsablauf konfigurierte Genehmigungsworkflow (id:..........)  ist nicht mehr vorhanden.

Ich möchte diese tägliche Benachrichtigung ausstellen, finde aber keinen Hinweis wie bzw. wo!

Dementsprechend habe ich mich entschlossen, die Community zu Fragen.

 

Im Voraus vielen Dank für die Unterstützung.
